title-group.article-title: Illiquid Securities: Pricing and Performance Measurement

abstract.p: Traditionally, the pricing of illiquid securities has relied heavily on subjective assumptions about yields and yield spreads. Benchmarks for the performance of such securities did not exist, hence their risk and return characteristics were not well understood. With the increasing interest in illiquid securities on the part of various institutional investors, not to mention proposed regulations covering reporting for such investments, the need for an objective pricing framework would seem to be evident. Information on prices in public fixed-income markets provides some help in valuing illiquid securities but does not address the fundamental issues. In particular, the credit quality of the security and its issuer, as well as changes in these parameters over time, must be taken into account. A pricing model based on default risk (a certainty equivalent model) explicitly incorporates a credit risk assessment model and capital structure theory into a valuation approach that provides objectivity and avoids the interference of short-term trading noise. Indexes of publicly traded fixed-income securities can be used as a basis for illiquid asset performance benchmarks, as long as appropriate adjustments are made to reflect the unique nature of illiquid investments. Construction of a replicable and investable commercial mortgage performance benchmark shows how this can be done.
